Similarly, ACE2 has a protective effect in the lungs. ACE2 is expressed primarily in alveolar epithelial type II cells in the normal adult lung
110â€“ 112 . These cells produce surfactant proteins that reduce surface tension, preventing the alveoli from collapsing. In a mouse model of ARDS, Ace2 knockout exacerbated acute lung injury, whereas treatment with recombinant ACE2 rescued lung damage
106 . Therefore, like SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2 infection might result in the downregulation of ACE2, which can lead to cardiac dysfunction and progression of atherosclerosis, as well as exacerbated lung damage.
